content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Angela Williams: I was born in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania, but I moved to the United States when I was just five years old. My parents were both teachers, and they worked hard to give me and my younger brother a good education. Life was tough in the beginning—my father passed away when I was 13, which was a huge loss for our family. My mother took on extra jobs to keep us afloat, and she always made sure we had what we needed, even if it wasn't much. I grew up in a small apartment in Brooklyn, and I remember walking to school every day, often missing breakfast because we couldn't afford much. I was a quiet kid, but I loved reading and writing. I got into a community college right after high school, and I worked part-time at a local bookstore to help pay for my tuition. I eventually transferred to a four-year university in North Carolina, where I earned my bachelor's degree in English. I've been working full-time as a content writer for the past six years, and I've been living in Raleigh for about four years now. I'm divorced, and I have a son who's eight years old. He lives with me, and I'm trying to give him the stability I didn't always have. I speak Swahili at home, and I still keep in touch with my extended family in Tanzania. Life hasn't always been easy, but I've learned to be resilient and to find strength in the little things.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Angela Williams: Yes, there was a moment that really shaped the course of my life. It happened when I was 17, right after my father passed away. I was in high school, and I felt like the world had shifted beneath me. My mother was working two jobs, and I was struggling to keep up with school while also trying to help out at home. I remember one night, after working late at the bookstore where I had my first part-time job, I sat down and thought about my future. I realized that if I didn't take control of my education, I might end up stuck in the same cycle of poverty that my parents had fought so hard to escape. So I made a decision—I would apply to community college the next semester, even if it meant working even more hours to afford it. That choice led me to a scholarship opportunity I wouldn't have known about otherwise, and it opened doors I never imagined. It was a tough path, but it taught me the power of perseverance and the importance of making choices that align with your long-term goals, even when the road ahead is uncertain.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Angela Williams: I think for me, it was a conscious choice, but not one I made lightly. It felt like I was standing at the edge of a cliff, and I had to decide whether to step back into the safety of the familiar or take the leap into something unknown. I didn't have a lot of resources or support, but I had my mother's example—she never gave up, even when things were impossible. I remember telling myself, 'If she could do it, then so can I.' That moment wasn't just about education; it was about taking responsibility for my future and not letting my circumstances define me. I didn't have a grand plan, but I had a clear goal: to break the cycle. And I knew that if I didn't act, I might never have the chance again.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Angela Williams: Absolutely. I think if I had reached out to someone or accessed the right resources, it might have made things a little easier. But at the time, I didn't know where to start. My mother was doing everything she could, but she didn't have the time or the connections to help me navigate college applications or scholarships. I remember thinking that asking for help would be a sign of weakness, especially in our community where people often pride themselves on being self-reliant. Looking back, I wish I had been more open to support—whether it was from teachers, mentors, or even local organizations. There were a few teachers at my high school who saw potential in me and encouraged me to apply for scholarships, but I was too scared to take them up on it. It wasn't until I was already in community college that I realized how much I had missed out on. So, yes, I think a helping hand could have made a difference, but I also think it took me a while to recognize that I needed one.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Angela Williams: I currently don't have a partner, but I have an eight-year-old son named Elijah who lives with me. He's a bright and curious kid, and I try my best to be there for him every day. His father and I were married for about five years, but the marriage didn't last. It was a tough time for both of us, but I'm grateful that we've maintained a civil relationship for his sake. Elijah is a big fan of superheroes and loves to read—just like I did when I was his age. I try to read to him every night, and it's one of the few moments where I feel like I'm giving him the kind of childhood I wish I'd had. My mother is still very involved in his life, and she helps out as much as she can. I also have a younger brother who's in his early twenties, and we stay in touch through calls and messages. He's just starting out in his career, and I try to be a source of support for him as well. Family has always been important to me, even when things got difficult, and I want to make sure that Elijah knows how much he's loved and valued.

Going through those interview questions brought back a lot of memories and reflections about my journey. It was humbling to revisit the challenges I faced growing up, especially after my father's passing and the struggles we had financially. I never thought about how much of my life was shaped by that one decision at 17 to pursue education, even when it felt impossible. It's funny how something so small at the time—choosing to apply to community college—ended up changing everything. I also realized how much I missed out on by not reaching out for help when I needed it most. Now, as a mother, I'm determined to be different. I want Elijah to know that it's okay to ask for help, that it's okay to dream big, and that no matter how hard life gets, you can always find a way forward. I hope my story can inspire others who are facing their own crossroads, even if they don't see the path clearly yet.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Angela Williams: My immediate family includes my mother, my younger brother, and my son Elijah. I also have two cousins who live in Dar es Salaam, and we keep in touch through letters and video calls. My relationship with my mother is very close—she's been my rock through everything, and I admire her strength and resilience. My brother and I have always had a good relationship, even though we grew up in different parts of the country. He's been through his own struggles, but he's doing well now. As for my cousins, they remind me of my roots and the culture I grew up with. Even though I was born in Tanzania, I feel like I belong to both places—my heart is here in the U.S., but my soul is still tied to Africa. I try to share stories from my childhood with Elijah, so he can understand where I'm from and where his heritage comes from. It's important to me that he feels connected to both sides of his identity.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Angela Williams: Outside of my family, there are a few friends who have been there for me through thick and thin. One of them is Maria, a coworker I met when I first started at the content writing company. She's been a great support system, especially during the divorce and the early years of raising Elijah alone. We've been friends for over a decade now, and she's the one who encouraged me to start writing my own stories—both professionally and personally. There's also a mentor from my community college days, Mr. Thompson, who was the first to really believe in me and push me to apply for that scholarship that changed everything. I still keep in touch with him, and he's been a steady presence in my life. Then there's my best friend from high school, Aisha, who moved to Raleigh a few years back. We don't see each other as often as I'd like, but when we do, it's like no time has passed. She's the one who reminded me of my dreams when I was feeling lost. These people, in their own ways, have helped shape who I am today, and I'm grateful for their presence in my life.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Angela Williams: I live in a neighborhood in Raleigh called Willow Creek, which is a mix of older homes and newer developments. It's a pretty quiet area, with lots of trees and green spaces, which I really appreciate after growing up in a more crowded city. There's a small park nearby where Elijah and I like to go on weekends—sometimes we have a picnic, or he plays with the other kids. The community here is pretty tight-knit, and I've made a few friends through the local library and the parent-teacher association at his school. I love that there are a lot of families here, and it feels like a safe place for him to grow up. I also enjoy the diversity in the area—there are people from all different backgrounds, which reminds me of my own heritage. It's not perfect, of course, and there are challenges, but overall, I feel lucky to have found a place where I can build a life for myself and my son.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Angela Williams: I feel pretty safe here, honestly. It's not the kind of safety that comes from never having anything to worry about, but it's the kind where I can walk to the park with Elijah without feeling anxious, and I know the neighbors look out for one another. There have been a few moments where I've felt the weight of the world, especially during the early days of raising him alone, but the sense of community here has been a real comfort. I think it's also helped that I've made an effort to get involved—whether it's volunteering at the library or attending school events. It's given me a sense of belonging that I didn't always have before. I know safety isn't just about the environment, though—it's also about feeling secure in your own life, and I'm working every day to make sure Elijah has that.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Angela Williams: Living here in Willow Creek has had its ups and downs, just like anywhere else. The quiet, the green spaces, the sense of community—it's all really comforting, especially after growing up in a more chaotic environment. But there are moments when I feel the weight of being a single mother in a place that, while welcoming, still has its own set of challenges. Sometimes, I worry about whether I'm giving Elijah everything he needs, especially when I'm working long hours at the office. I've had to learn how to balance my job, my son's needs, and my own well-being, and it's not always easy. But there are also so many positives. The local library is a haven for us—Elijah loves the storytime sessions, and I've found a lot of support there from other parents. I've also started volunteering with a literacy program for kids, which feels like a way to give back to the community that's helped me so much. It's not perfect, but I'm learning to find joy in the small things, and that's something I want to teach Elijah too.

Going through the interview questions about my family and current neighborhood made me reflect on how much my life has changed since I was a child. It's strange to think about how far I've come—from growing up in a small apartment in Brooklyn to now living in a quiet, green neighborhood in Raleigh with my son. I've learned that family, whether blood-related or through friendship, is what truly supports you through life's challenges. My son Elijah is my greatest joy, and I want to make sure he grows up in a safe, loving environment, just like I wish I had. The sense of community here in Willow Creek has been a blessing, and I'm grateful for the people who have helped me along the way. It's comforting to know that even though life hasn't always been easy, I've found a place where I can build a better future for myself and my child.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Angela Williams: A typical week for me is pretty structured, but it's also full of unexpected moments. I usually start my week on Monday with Elijah and me heading to the library early in the morning—his storytime is one of his favorite things, and it gives me a chance to catch up on some work or planning. I work from home most of the time as a content writer, so my days are a mix of writing, meetings, and deadlines. I try to keep a routine, but it's not always easy. Midweek, I often take Elijah to his after-school program, which is run by a local nonprofit. It's a great place for him to be creative and social, and it gives me a few hours to focus on work or run errands. Fridays are usually the busiest day for me because I have to pick him up, do some grocery shopping, and sometimes attend a parent-teacher meeting or a community event. On weekends, we like to go to the park or visit the local farmer's market. I also try to set aside some time for myself—whether it's reading, cooking, or just sitting in the garden and thinking. Life is busy, but I've learned to find peace in the rhythm of it, and I hope Elijah can too.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Angela Williams: I work as a content writer for a digital marketing firm based in Raleigh. My job is mostly remote, which gives me the flexibility to work from home and be there for Elijah when I need to be. I usually start my workday around 9 a.m., after dropping Elijah off at his after-school program or taking him to school. My days are filled with writing blog posts, editing content, and collaborating with my team through video calls. I work about 40 hours a week, though sometimes it stretches a bit longer when there's a tight deadline. I've been in this field for six years now, and while it's not always glamorous, I enjoy the creativity and the fact that I can make an impact through words. It's also given me the financial stability I need to provide for my son, which is something I never took for granted growing up. I often think about how far I've come—from working part-time at a bookstore to writing for companies that reach thousands of people. It's a humbling reminder of how much hard work and perseverance can change your life.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Angela Williams: Outside of work and taking care of Elijah, I also have a few other routines that keep me grounded. Every evening, after I get home from work, I try to have a quiet dinner with him, even if it's just simple food—sometimes we make pizza from scratch, which is something we both enjoy. After dinner, I help him with his homework or read to him, and then we usually have a bedtime routine that includes a story and some light conversation. I also make it a point to go to the local community center a couple of times a week for a yoga class—it's a small group, and it's been a great way to stay healthy and meet other single parents who understand the challenges we face. On the weekends, I like to cook meals in bulk and freeze them for the week, which helps me manage my time better. I also have a small garden in the backyard where I grow herbs and some vegetables. It's not much, but it's my way of connecting with the land and remembering where I came from. These little things, the routines and rituals, are what keep me balanced and help me be the best version of myself for Elijah.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Angela Williams: One of the recent changes to my daily routine has been starting a small writing group for single parents in the neighborhood. I've been sharing my own experiences and encouraging others to express themselves through writing, whether it's journaling, storytelling, or even creative writing. It started as a way to cope with the stress of being a single mother, but it quickly became something more—something that brought me closer to others who were going through similar struggles. I also began teaching Elijah how to write short stories, which has been a bonding experience for us. It's amazing how much he's picked up, and it's given me a new perspective on how important it is to nurture creativity from a young age. I've also started waking up a little earlier in the mornings to meditate and journal before the day begins, which has helped me stay centered and focused. These small changes, while not dramatic, have made a big difference in how I approach each day and how I show up for Elijah.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Angela Williams: A typical weekday during the school year for Elijah starts early—usually around 7 a.m. I wake him up, and we have a quick breakfast together, often something simple like toast with peanut butter or oatmeal. After that, we head to the library for his storytime session, which is one of his favorite parts of the morning. Once we get back home, he has a little time to play or do some quiet activities before I leave for work. He usually spends the rest of the day at the after-school program, which is run by a local nonprofit called Bright Futures. They offer a variety of activities—art, music, and even some light sports. I know it's a safe and supportive environment, and I appreciate how it helps him stay engaged and creative while I'm at work. When I pick him up in the afternoon, we usually have a snack, and then I help him with his homework or read to him. I try to make sure he has a consistent bedtime routine, so we wind down with a story and some light conversation. It's not always perfect, but I feel lucky to have a routine that works for us, and I hope it gives him a sense of stability and love.

Going through the interview questions about my family and current neighborhood made me reflect on how much my life has changed since I was a child. It's strange to think about how far I've come—from growing up in a small apartment in Brooklyn to now living in a quiet, green neighborhood in Raleigh with my son. I've learned that family, whether blood-related or through friendship, is what truly supports you through life's challenges. My son Elijah is my greatest joy, and I want to make sure he grows up in a safe, loving environment, just like I wish I had. The sense of community here in Willow Creek has been a blessing, and I'm grateful for the people who have helped me along the way. It's comforting to know that even though life hasn't always been easy, I've found a place where I can build a better future for myself and my child.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Angela Williams: My health has been something I've had to be mindful of, especially since becoming a single mother. I used to be pretty active growing up, running around Brooklyn with my brother and playing soccer in the park, but after having Elijah and working long hours, I haven't been as consistent with exercise as I'd like. I do my best to stay healthy—eating balanced meals, trying to get enough sleep, and making sure I take time for myself when I can. I've had some struggles with stress and anxiety, especially in the early days after the divorce, but I've been working on managing it through meditation and talking to friends I trust. I also started seeing a therapist a few months ago, which has been really helpful. It's not always easy, but I've come to realize that taking care of my health isn't just about me—it's about being there for Elijah, too. I want him to see that taking care of yourself is just as important as taking care of others.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Angela Williams: What makes it easy to stay healthy is knowing that I have a small but consistent routine—like my yoga classes at the community center and the little garden in the backyard. Those things ground me and remind me that I'm not just surviving, but living. What makes it hard is the constant juggling act between work, Elijah's needs, and my own well-being. There are days when I forget to eat properly or skip a meditation session because I'm too busy or too tired. I also struggle with the emotional weight of being a single mother, and sometimes that affects my motivation to take care of myself. But I'm learning that even small steps—like taking a walk after work or making sure I drink enough water—can make a difference. I'm not perfect, but I'm trying, and that's what matters most.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Angela Williams: In the past two years, I actually went through a pretty significant health challenge. I was diagnosed with hypothyroidism last year, which came as a bit of a surprise. I had been feeling sluggish for a while, always tired no matter how much sleep I got, and I noticed my hair was thinning and my skin was dry. At first, I just thought it was stress or the demands of being a single mom, but my doctor ran some tests and found that my thyroid wasn't producing enough hormones. Once I started taking the medication, things slowly began to improve—my energy levels came back, and I felt more like myself again. It was a wake-up call, though. It made me realize how important it is to listen to my body and not ignore the signs. I also started eating more mindfully and making sure I wasn't skipping meals, which helped a lot. It wasn't easy at first, but I'm grateful for the diagnosis because it gave me the tools to take better care of myself. Now, I make sure to check in with my doctor regularly and keep track of how I'm feeling. It's one more way I'm learning to prioritize my health, not just for me, but for Elijah too.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Angela Williams: At first, the hypothyroidism did make things a little harder. I was so tired all the time that I found myself struggling to keep up with work and Elijah's needs. There were days when I would just sit on the couch and feel like I couldn't move, and I worried that I wasn't being the mother or the professional I wanted to be. But once I started taking the medication and made some changes to my lifestyle, it got better. I learned that I couldn't push through everything on my own—I had to ask for help when I needed it, whether it was from my therapist, my friends, or even just taking a few minutes to breathe when I felt overwhelmed. It also made me more aware of how important it is to take care of myself, not just for my own sake, but because Elijah needs me to be strong and present. Now, I try to be more proactive about my health, and I've started setting aside time each day to check in with how I'm feeling. It's not always easy, but I'm learning that taking care of myself is part of being a good parent, and that's something I want to model for Elijah.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Angela Williams: Over the past year, I've felt a mix of emotions—some days I feel like I'm making progress, and other days I feel like I'm just barely keeping my head above water. Becoming a single mother was already a huge adjustment, but adding the challenge of managing my health on top of that made things even more complicated. There were times when I felt like I wasn't doing enough for Elijah or for myself, and I worried that I was setting a bad example. But I've also learned so much about resilience, about how to ask for help, and about the importance of small, consistent efforts. I've started to see that progress doesn't always look like a big leap—it can be as simple as getting out of bed on a tough morning or taking a few deep breaths when the world feels too heavy. I'm still learning, and I'm still growing, but I feel more hopeful than I have in a long time. I want Elijah to see that life isn't always easy, but it's always worth fighting for.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 16 to 20 made me reflect on how much my life has evolved, especially in terms of my health and daily routines. It's strange to think about how I used to take my well-being for granted, not realizing how much it would impact my ability to care for Elijah and do my job. Starting the writing group for single parents was a turning point for me—it gave me a sense of purpose beyond just being a mother and a worker. It also reminded me how important it is to take care of myself, even in small ways, like meditating in the morning or tending to my garden. I've come to understand that my health isn't just about physical well-being, but also about emotional resilience and the strength to ask for help when I need it. These changes, though small, have helped me build a more balanced life for myself and for Elijah. I'm learning that being a mother doesn't mean I have to do everything alone, and that taking care of myself is just as important as taking care of him.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Angela Williams: I think I've struggled with anxiety more than anything else, especially in the early years after the divorce and when I was trying to balance work, Elijah, and my health. There were days when I felt like I was drowning in responsibilities, and I worried that I wasn't doing enough for my son or that I'd never be able to get ahead. I remember one night, after a particularly stressful day, I sat in the kitchen with a cup of tea and just cried—didn't even know why, just felt like everything was too much. But over time, I've learned to recognize the signs and take steps to manage it. Talking to my therapist, meditating, and even just having a few minutes to myself have made a huge difference. I still have bad days, but I no longer feel like I'm alone in this. I've learned that it's okay to not be okay, and that asking for help is a sign of strength, not weakness. I want Elijah to know that it's okay to feel overwhelmed sometimes, and that it's okay to take a breath and ask for support when you need it.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Angela Williams: For my family, it's been a journey of learning and growing together. Elijah has been through a lot in his young life—watching his parents go through a divorce, adjusting to living with just me, and dealing with the challenges that come with being a single parent. But he's a resilient kid, and I've seen him develop a strength that I didn't expect. He's always been curious and kind, and I think those traits have helped him navigate the changes in our lives. My mother has been a constant support, and even though she's not always here in person, her love and guidance have been a huge part of his life. I know she worries about him, just like I do, but I also know she's proud of the way he's growing. As for me, I've learned that being a mother doesn't mean I have to have all the answers or be perfect—it means showing up, even on the hard days, and being there for him when he needs me most. I think we're all still learning, but I feel like we're moving in the right direction, and that gives me hope for the future.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Angela Williams: I would say that religion hasn't been a big part of my life in the way it was for my family when I was growing up. My parents were Protestant, and we attended church regularly when I was a child. But as I got older, I found myself questioning a lot of the things I was taught, and eventually, I drifted away from organized religion. Now, I don't identify with any specific faith, but I do believe in something bigger than myself—whether that's the strength of the human spirit, the resilience of my community, or the love I feel for my son. I think of it more as a personal kind of spirituality, something that helps me stay grounded and connected to the world around me. I don't need a church to feel that, and I don't think it's something I need to explain or justify. What matters most to me is living with intention, being kind, and making sure Elijah knows that he's loved no matter what. I think that's its own kind of faith.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Angela Williams: I don't use social media very often, to be honest. I find that it can be both a distraction and a source of stress, especially when I'm trying to focus on work or spend quality time with Elijah. I do have a Facebook account, mostly to stay in touch with family back in Tanzania and some old friends from high school. I post rarely—maybe a photo of Elijah doing something cute or a simple update about our day. I don't follow a lot of people, and I tend to unfollow accounts that make me feel worse about myself or my life. I think social media can be a double-edged sword. On one hand, it's a way to connect with people who matter, but on the other hand, it can make you feel like you're not enough if you're not constantly sharing or comparing yourself to others. I've learned to use it mindfully, if at all, and I prefer spending my time in the real world—whether it's in the garden, at the library, or just talking to Elijah. He's my main connection to the world, and I think that's enough.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Angela Williams: Honestly, I haven't really relied on social media for support during tough times. I think I've always been more of a private person, and I find that the more I post, the more I feel like I'm putting on a mask instead of being real. When I was going through the divorce and raising Elijah alone, I didn't turn to Facebook or Twitter for comfort—I turned to my mother, my friends, and the people in my community. They were the ones who showed up, who listened, and who reminded me that I wasn't alone. I think social media can be a place for connection, but it's not the same as real, face-to-face support. I've seen people post about their struggles and get a lot of likes, but sometimes it feels like they're just performing for an audience instead of truly being seen. For me, it's always been about the people I know and love, not the people I follow online. I don't need a virtual crowd to feel supported—I have enough real ones already.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 21 to 25 made me reflect on how much my health and mental well-being have shaped the past year of my life. It's been a challenging journey, especially with the diagnosis of hypothyroidism and the ongoing struggle with anxiety. I used to think that being strong meant pushing through everything on my own, but now I understand that asking for help is a sign of strength, not weakness. I've learned to take my health more seriously, whether it's through medication, therapy, or small daily habits like meditation and journaling. It's also helped me realize that my mental health directly affects my ability to be the best mother I can be for Elijah. I want him to see that it's okay to feel overwhelmed and that it's okay to take a breath and ask for support when you need it. These lessons have been hard-earned, but they're ones I'm grateful for, and I hope they help both me and Elijah navigate life with more grace and resilience.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Angela Williams: In the past year, my stress levels have definitely fluctuated, but I've been working on developing healthier coping strategies. There were times when I felt like I was carrying the weight of the world on my shoulders—especially when I was juggling work deadlines, Elijah's school activities, and my own health challenges. But I've started to recognize that stress isn't something I have to face alone. I've been more open about my feelings with my friends and even with Elijah, which has helped me feel less isolated. I also started journaling more regularly, which has been a great way to process my thoughts and emotions without holding them in. I've found that even small things—like taking a walk in the garden or listening to music while cooking—can help me reset and feel more centered. I'm still learning, and there are definitely days when I feel overwhelmed, but I'm trying to be kinder to myself and to acknowledge that it's okay to not be perfect. I want Elijah to see that it's okay to feel stressed sometimes, but that there are ways to manage it and find peace in the chaos.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Angela Williams: Last month, my biggest expenses were rent, groceries, and Elijah's school-related costs. Rent for our home in Willow Creek is about $1,200 a month, which is a chunk of my income, but I'm grateful that the neighborhood is affordable compared to other places in Raleigh. Groceries are another big one—between meals, snacks, and the occasional treat for Elijah, I usually spend around $400 to $500 each month. I also have to factor in his school supplies, uniforms, and after-school program fees, which add up to about $200. On top of that, I still have some medical expenses from my hypothyroidism medication and therapy sessions, which are around $150. I try to budget carefully, and I've gotten pretty good at tracking my spending with a simple spreadsheet. I also set aside a small amount each month for savings, even if it's just $50—because I know that having a little cushion can make all the difference when things get tight. It's not always easy, but I've learned to prioritize what matters most, and that's being able to provide for Elijah and take care of my health.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Angela Williams: Last month, our household spent around $2,100, which is pretty close to what we usually spend each month. The majority of that goes to rent, groceries, and Elijah's school-related expenses, as I mentioned earlier. I also have to account for my car payment, which is about $250 a month, and utilities like electricity and internet, which run around $150. I try to keep our spending as consistent as possible, but there are always a few unexpected costs—like when Elijah needs a new pair of shoes or when I have to replace something in the house. I've learned to be pretty frugal, and I make sure we only buy what we need. I also try to cook most of our meals at home to save money, and I've gotten pretty good at meal planning. It's not always easy, especially when I'm working long hours and trying to be there for Elijah, but I've come to accept that this is just part of the rhythm of our life. What matters most is that we're stable, and I'm doing my best to make sure we have everything we need.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Angela Williams: We rent our home. It's a two-bedroom apartment in Willow Creek, and while it's not the biggest place, it's cozy and feels like a safe haven for both Elijah and me. Renting has been the practical choice for us right now—especially with my income as a content writer and the cost of living in Raleigh. I don't have a lot of savings, so buying a home isn't really an option at this point. But I'm not worried about it. I know that stability comes in many forms, and for now, this place feels like home. It's also close to the library, Elijah's school, and the community center where I take my yoga classes. I like knowing that we're in a place where we can build a life, even if it's not permanent. I just hope that one day, when Elijah is older and we have more financial security, we can think about buying a house—but for now, renting works for us.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Angela Williams: Over the past year, my bills have definitely had their ups and downs, depending on the season and what was going on with Elijah. For example, during the winter months, my heating bill went up a bit, and I had to spend more on groceries because I was cooking more at home to save money. Then, when school started back up in the fall, there were additional costs for supplies, uniforms, and the after-school program. I also noticed that my medical expenses fluctuated a little—some months I had more therapy sessions, and other months I had to buy new medication or pay for check-ups. Around the holidays, I tried to be careful with spending, but there were still some unexpected costs, like a new winter coat for Elijah or a few small gifts for family back in Tanzania. I've learned to track everything more closely now, and I've started setting aside a little extra each month for these kinds of surprises. It's not always perfect, but I'm getting better at planning ahead and making sure we don't get caught off guard.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 26 to 30 made me reflect on how much my family and my approach to support—both emotional and practical—have shaped my life. It's been a journey of learning that I don't have to face everything alone, whether it's raising Elijah, managing my health, or navigating the challenges of being a single mother. My family, especially my mother, has been a constant source of strength, and I've come to realize that true support doesn't always come from grand gestures—it can be in the small, everyday moments of love and encouragement. I also think about how I've chosen to rely on real, meaningful connections rather than turning to social media for validation or comfort. It's comforting to know that the people I love are the ones who truly understand me, and that's what I want to pass on to Elijah. I want him to grow up knowing that it's okay to lean on others, that support is a gift, not a weakness, and that the people who matter most are the ones who show up, even when life gets hard.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Angela Williams: I do save, though it's not always a lot. I have a small savings account that I try to contribute to every month, even if it's just $50. It's not much, but it gives me a sense of security, knowing that there's something there if things get tight. I also save in other ways—like growing my own herbs and vegetables in the garden, which helps cut down on grocery costs. I've learned that saving doesn't always have to be about money; it can be about time, resources, or even emotional resilience. I try to be intentional with what I spend and what I hold onto, because I know that for Elijah and me, every little bit helps. It's not about having a lot, but about being prepared for the unexpected and making sure we can weather any storm that comes our way.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Angela Williams: For me, saving has mostly been about preparing for the unexpected—like medical expenses, car repairs, or a sudden need for something Elijah might require. I know that life can change in an instant, and I want to make sure I'm not caught off guard. I also save in smaller ways, like setting aside a few dollars each week for emergencies or special occasions. I don't dream of buying a house right now, but I do hope to build a more stable financial foundation for Elijah so that he has options when he's older. It's not about having a lot, but about being responsible and thoughtful with what I have. I've learned that saving isn't just about money—it's about creating a sense of security, not just for me, but for the people I love.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Angela Williams: My occupation has been as a content writer, and it's been both a challenge and a blessing. The most important part of my job is creating written content that resonates with people—whether it's blog posts, social media updates, or marketing materials. I spend a lot of time researching topics, understanding the audience, and making sure the tone and message align with what the client is looking for. I also collaborate with editors and designers to ensure the content fits into a larger campaign or strategy. One of the things I love most about this work is the creativity it allows—every project is different, and I get to express myself in ways that feel meaningful. At the same time, it can be stressful when deadlines are tight or when the feedback isn't what I hoped for. But I've learned to see those moments as part of the process, and I try to stay focused on the bigger picture: telling stories that matter and making an impact, even if it's just in small ways.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Angela Williams: I usually work around 40 hours a week, though it can sometimes stretch a bit longer when there are tight deadlines or projects that need extra attention. Since I work remotely, my schedule is pretty flexible, but I try to stick to a routine—starting around 9 a.m. and wrapping up by 5 or 6 p.m., depending on how much I have to finish. I find that having a set schedule helps me stay productive, especially with Elijah around. Some days, I work from my home office, and other days, I take him to the library or a quiet café so I can focus without distractions. I also make sure to take breaks throughout the day, whether it's for a quick walk or just to check in with him. It's not always easy balancing work and parenting, but I've learned to be efficient with my time and to ask for help when I need it—whether it's from my mother, my friends, or even Elijah himself, who's gotten pretty good at reminding me when it's time to take a break.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Angela Williams: No, I haven't had more than one job at the same time. I've focused on building a stable career as a content writer because I know how important it is to have a steady income, especially as a single mother. There were a few times when I considered taking on extra gigs or part-time work to supplement my income, but I always hesitated because I didn't want to overextend myself or compromise the time I had with Elijah. I remember one particular moment when I was offered a freelance writing project that would have paid well, but it would have required late nights and weekends. I had to say no because I knew I couldn't be the kind of mother Elijah needed if I was constantly working. It was a hard decision, but I've come to realize that my job isn't just about earning money—it's about being present for him, even when it's difficult. I've also learned to be more strategic about my work, like taking on projects that are flexible or that allow me to work from home, so I can still be there for Elijah when he needs me most.

I'm still learning, but I feel more grounded than I have in a long time, and I hope that sense of balance and resilience continues to grow in both my life and Elijah's.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Angela Williams: In total, my household made around $3,200 in the past month. That comes from my full-time job as a content writer, and I'm lucky to have a steady income that covers most of our needs. I don't make a ton, but I've learned to live within my means and prioritize what truly matters. I also occasionally take on small freelance writing gigs when I have the time, which helps supplement our budget a little. It's not always easy, especially when I'm working late or dealing with health issues, but I've come to accept that this is the reality for many single parents. What I'm most proud of is that I've managed to provide Elijah with a stable home, good food, and the opportunity to grow and learn. I know we're not wealthy, but I believe that happiness and security don't always come from having a lot—they come from knowing you're doing your best, and that you're loved.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Angela Williams: I've been at my current job for about six years now, and it's been a journey of growth and learning. The company offers a few benefits, like health insurance, which has been a lifesaver, especially since I was diagnosed with hypothyroidism last year. I also get a certain number of paid days off, which I try to use for rest, family time, or even just a day to myself when I need it most. The flexibility of working remotely has been a huge blessing, especially as a single mother—it allows me to be there for Elijah without having to commute long hours or miss important moments. I don't have a lot of vacation days, but I do appreciate the sick time, because there are days when I just need to take a step back and focus on my health. Overall, I'm grateful for the stability this job provides, even if it's not perfect. It's given me the chance to build a career I can be proud of, and that's something I want to pass on to Elijah—showing him that hard work and dedication can lead to a better life, even if it's not always easy.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Angela Williams: My relationships at work have been pretty positive overall. I've been lucky to have a manager who's supportive and understands the challenges of balancing work and life, especially as a single parent. She's never made me feel like I had to choose between being a good employee or being there for Elijah. In fact, she's been flexible with my schedule when I needed to adjust for school events or medical appointments. As for my coworkers, most of them are friendly and understanding. We don't always have deep conversations, but there's a sense of mutual respect. I've had a few coworkers who have become good friends, and I really appreciate the camaraderie. It's not always easy being a remote worker, but the company has made an effort to foster a sense of community, even online. I think the key to my good relationships at work is that I try to be professional, kind, and open to collaboration. I've learned that showing up with a positive attitude goes a long way, and I'm grateful for the people I work with who make this job more than just a paycheck—it's also a place where I feel valued and supported.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Angela Williams: My work schedule is pretty predictable, but there's also a fair amount of flexibility, which I really appreciate. I usually start around 9 a.m., but if I need to adjust my hours for a school event or a doctor's appointment, my manager is usually understanding. Most of my projects have deadlines, so I have to plan my time accordingly, but I don't have to be in the office at a specific time every day. That flexibility has been a huge help, especially as a single mother. I can work from my home office in the morning, take Elijah to the library or his after-school program, and then come back to finish up the rest of my work in the evening if needed. It's not always perfect—there are days when I have to stay late to meet a deadline, or when I have to work on weekends if a project is behind—but overall, I feel like I have a good balance. The company allows me to set my own hours as long as I meet my goals, and that has made a big difference in how I manage my time and responsibilities.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Angela Williams: Overall, I feel like I'm in a place where I'm doing my best with what I have. It's not always easy, and there are days when I worry about whether I'm providing enough for Elijah or if I'm stretching too thin, but I've learned to be proud of the progress we've made. I know we're not wealthy, but we have what we need—food on the table, a safe place to live, and a sense of stability that I didn't have growing up. I've also come to accept that financial security isn't about having a lot; it's about having enough to feel secure and to give Elijah the opportunities I never had. I'm still learning, and there are definitely times when I feel the weight of it all, but I'm grateful for the small victories—the way Elijah is doing in school, the fact that I can afford my medication, and the peace of mind that comes from knowing I'm working hard to build a better future for both of us.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Angela Williams: Yes, my mom worked for pay for at least a year while I was growing up, and actually, she worked pretty consistently throughout my childhood. After my father passed away when I was 13, she took on two jobs to make sure we could keep our small apartment in Brooklyn and afford basic things like food, school supplies, and even a few extracurricular activities for me and my brother. She worked as a substitute teacher during the school year and did cleaning jobs on the weekends. I remember how tired she looked some days, but she never complained. She always made sure we had meals on the table and that we felt loved, even when things were hard. It wasn't easy for her, but she never let us see how much she was struggling. I think that's why I always felt a sense of responsibility to do well in school and make something of myself—because I knew she was working so hard to give us a chance. Now, as a mother myself, I try to be just as strong and resilient as she was, even when life feels overwhelming.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Angela Williams: My mother worked as a substitute teacher during the school year and did cleaning jobs on the weekends. Her most important activities were making sure we had food on the table, keeping our small apartment clean, and helping us with our schoolwork whenever she could. She was always juggling between her two jobs, but she never let us see how exhausted she was. I remember her coming home late at night, sometimes with a tired look in her eyes, but she would always smile and ask how my day was. She would sit with us for dinner, even if it was just simple food like rice and beans, and listen to us talk about our day. I think the most important part of her job was not just the money—it was the sense of stability she provided for us. Even when things were hard, she made sure we felt safe and loved. That's something I carry with me every day, and it's why I try to be as present and supportive for Elijah as she was for me.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Angela Williams: My mother worked for the public school system as a substitute teacher, and she also did cleaning jobs for a few different businesses in Brooklyn. The substitute teaching was through the district, and she would get called in whenever a regular teacher was out sick or on leave. It wasn't the most stable job, but it gave her a sense of purpose and a way to connect with the kids in the classroom. The cleaning jobs were more sporadic—sometimes she'd clean offices, sometimes she'd do residential work. I remember her coming home with her hands always a little sore from scrubbing floors or mopping, but she never complained. What she made wasn't much, but it was enough to keep us afloat. I think the most important thing she did was show us that hard work and resilience could get you through even the toughest times. She didn't have a lot, but she gave us everything she could, and that's something I'll never forget.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Angela Williams: I hope that in a few years, I'm still here in Willow Creek, but maybe with a little more stability—perhaps we've saved enough to buy a small home, or at least have more financial security so I don't have to worry about every dollar I spend. I hope Elijah is growing into a kind, curious, and confident young man, someone who knows his worth and isn't afraid to dream big. I want him to have the opportunities I never had, whether that's going to college, traveling, or just having the freedom to explore his passions without limits. I also hope that I'm still doing the work I love, writing, but maybe with more time to focus on my own stories, not just the ones I write for clients. I want to be the kind of mother who shows him that life is full of challenges, but also full of possibilities. And I hope that I'm still surrounded by the people who matter most—my mother, my friends, and the community that has supported me through it all. I don't know exactly what the future holds, but I hope it's one where I can look back and say I did my best, and that I gave Elijah a chance to live a life filled with love, hope, and resilience.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Angela Williams: What I value the most in my life is the love and connection I have with my son, Elijah. He is my greatest joy and my reason for getting up every morning. I also value the strength and resilience that I've learned through my own experiences—knowing that even in the darkest moments, there's always a way forward. I value the support of my mother, who has been my anchor through everything, and the friendships I've built with people like Maria, Mr. Thompson, and Aisha, who have helped shape who I am. I value the small, everyday moments that bring me peace—the sound of Elijah laughing, the smell of fresh herbs in my garden, the quiet of a morning walk. I value the lessons I've learned about asking for help, about being kind to myself, and about finding strength in the little things. Most of all, I value the hope that I can give Elijah a better life than the one I had, and the belief that no matter how hard things get, we can always find a way to keep moving forward.

From growing up in a small apartment in Brooklyn to now living in a quiet neighborhood in Raleigh with my son, I've learned that resilience isn't just about surviving—it's about thriving, even when life feels heavy. I've also learned that it's okay to ask for help, whether it's from family, friends, or even the community around me. I used to think that being strong meant carrying everything on my own, but now I see that true strength comes from knowing when to lean on others. My son Elijah is my greatest joy, and I want to make sure he grows up in a safe, loving environment, just like I wish I had. I've also come to accept that financial stability doesn't always mean having a lot—it means making smart choices, prioritizing what truly matters, and finding peace in the small things. I'm still learning, and there are definitely days when I feel the weight of it all, but I'm grateful for the small victories—the way Elijah is doing in school, the fact that I can afford my medication, and the peace of mind that comes from knowing I'm working hard to build a better future for both of us. I'm also grateful for the support I've received from my manager and coworkers, who have made this job more than just a paycheck—it's a place where I feel valued and supported, even when life gets tough. I hope that my story can inspire others who are facing their own crossroads, even if they don't see the path clearly yet.
